title: Marcus Drum
text:
Marcus James Drum (born 1 May 1987) is an <a href="Australian%20rules%20football">Australian rules football</a>er who played in the <a href="Australian%20Football%20League">Australian Football League</a> (AFL) for the <a href="Fremantle%20Football%20Club">Fremantle Football Club</a> between 2006 and 2009 before he was traded to <a href="Geelong%20Football%20Club">Geelong</a> during the <a href="2009%20AFL%20Draft">2009 trade week</a>.
In July 2011 Geelong announced that Drum had retired due to ongoing injury problems. In October 2013 he joined as a player welfare manager.
Recruited from the <a href="Murray%20Bushrangers">Murray Bushrangers</a>, Drum is the nephew of former <a href="Geelong%20Football%20Club">Geelong</a> player, <a href="Fremantle%20Football%20Club">Fremantle</a> coach and current <a href="Victoria%20%28Australia%29">Victorian</a> <a href="National%20Party%20of%20Australia">Nationals</a> <a href="Victorian%20Legislative%20Council">MLC</a> <a href="Damian%20Drum">Damian Drum</a>. He is a nephew of champion Richmond player and coach <a href="Francis%20Bourke">Francis Bourke</a> and cousin of Richmond and North Melbourne player <a href="David%20Bourke">David Bourke</a>. He is also a cousin of Geelong and St Kilda player <a href="Steven%20King%20%28footballer%29">Steven King</a>, through their mothers. In the <a href="2005%20AFL%20Draft">2005 National Draft</a>, Drum was selected with the 10th overall draft pick.
AFL career.
Fremantle (2006–2009).
Drum played five games in the 2006 AFL season, and won Fremantle's Beacon Award for the best up-and-coming player at the club's <a href="Doig%20Medal">Doig Medal</a> dinner in October 2006.
He did not play until round 16 in the <a href="2007%20AFL%20season">2007 AFL season</a>, when new coach <a href="Mark%20Harvey">Mark Harvey</a> chose him in the squad to take on <a href="Adelaide%20Football%20Club">Adelaide</a> at <a href="AAMI%20Stadium">AAMI Stadium</a>. In a win for Fremantle, he kicked 4 handy goals for the team. However, he only played two more matches for the season, against <a href="Geelong%20Football%20Club">Geelong</a> in round 17 and <a href="Port%20Adelaide%20Football%20Club">Port Adelaide</a> in round 22. <a href="2008%20AFL%20season">2008</a> saw Drum play 9 games, his highest annual tally to date, including the final four matches. After playing in the opening round of the <a href="2009%20AFL%20season">2009 AFL season</a>, Drum didn't return to the AFL until Round 19, when he again played the final four games. During the season his form for <a href="Perth%20Football%20Club">Perth</a> in the <a href="West%20Australian%20Football%20League">WAFL</a> was poor, but despite this he was a surprise selection for the last four games.
During the <a href="2009%20AFL%20Draft">2009 AFL trade week</a>, Drum was traded to Geelong for a third round draft pick, number 49 overall.
Geelong (2010–2011).
Due to a succession of injuries, including a <a href="detached%20retina">detached retina</a> and injuries to his <a href="Achilles%20tendon">Achilles tendon</a> and <a href="hamstring">hamstring</a>, Drum struggled to play regularly for Geelong's side in the <a href="Victorian%20Football%20League">Victorian Football League</a> (VFL) and never made his senior debut for Geelong in the AFL. In the middle of the <a href="2011%20AFL%20season">2011 AFL season</a> he announced his retirement from AFL football after only playing 6 games in two seasons in the VFL.
